articles.headline: Temp Workers in Germany Dismay Unions
articles.snippet: Critics say that the loosening of regulations in 2003 allowing companies to hire temporary workers has created poorly paid employees.
articles.abstract: Critics say that the loosening of regulations in 2003 allowing companies to hire temporary workers has created poorly paid employees.
articles.lead_paragraph: FRANKFURT — Peter Hintermeier, a 60-year-old pipe fitter, is one of the people who have made Germany competitive again, but he is not too happy about it.

articles.headline: Administration Wants Tighter Painkiller Rules
articles.snippet: The Obama administration wants legislation requiring training for doctors who prescribe powerful painkillers.
articles.abstract: The Obama administration wants legislation requiring training for doctors who prescribe powerful painkillers.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Obama administration said on Tuesday that it would seek legislation requiring doctors to undergo training before being permitted to prescribe powerful painkillers like OxyContin, the most aggressive step taken by federal officials to control both the use and abuse of the drugs.
articles.byline: By Barry Meier and Abby Goodnough

articles.headline: As British Help Libyan Rebels, Aid Goes to a Divided Force
articles.snippet: British military advisers will find themselves overseeing a ragtag rebel force in Libya that cannot even agree on who its top officer is, amid squabbling between two generals.
articles.abstract: British military advisers will find themselves overseeing a ragtag rebel force in Libya that cannot even agree on who its top officer is, amid squabbling between two generals.
articles.lead_paragraph: BENGHAZI, Libya — As NATO struggles to break a deepening stalemate in Libya, the British announced on Tuesday that they were sending military advisers to help build up a rebel army that has stumbled against the superior forces of Col. Muammar el-Qaddafi.

articles.headline: Leader of Big Mortgage Lender Guilty of $2.9 Billion Fraud
articles.snippet: Prosecutors said the defendant, Lee Farkas, led a scheme of staggering proportions in a case arising from the nation’s financial crisis.
articles.abstract: Prosecutors said the defendant, Lee Farkas, led a scheme of staggering proportions in a case arising from the nation’s financial crisis.
articles.lead_paragraph: The founder of what was once one of the nation’s largest mortgage lenders was convicted of fraud on Tuesday for masterminding a scheme that cheated investors and the government out of billions of dollars. It is one of the few successful prosecutions to come out of the financial crisis.

articles.headline: Solar on the Water
articles.snippet: The potential of floating solar farms is enticing for some farmers, municipalities and companies that see their ponds and reservoirs doing double duty.
articles.abstract: The potential of floating solar farms is enticing for some farmers, municipalities and companies that see their ponds and reservoirs doing double duty.
articles.lead_paragraph: PETALUMA, Calif. — Solar panels have sprouted on countless rooftops, carports and fields in Northern California. Now, several start-up companies see potential for solar panels that float on water.

articles.headline: Ohio County Losing Its Young to Painkillers’ Grip
articles.snippet: Overdoses have surpassed car crashes as the leading cause of accidental deaths in Ohio.
articles.abstract: Overdoses have surpassed car crashes as the leading cause of accidental deaths in Ohio.
articles.lead_paragraph: PORTSMOUTH, Ohio — This industrial town was once known for its shoes and its steel. But after decades of decline it has made a name for itself for a different reason: it is home to some of the highest rates of prescription drug overdoses in the state, and growing numbers of younger victims.

articles.headline: U.S. Orders Airlines to State Fees More Clearly
articles.snippet: New rules will also increase the compensation passengers get when bumped from a flight, and will require a refund of baggage fees for lost luggage.
articles.abstract: New rules will also increase the compensation passengers get when bumped from a flight, and will require a refund of baggage fees for lost luggage.
articles.lead_paragraph: The government announced a new set of passenger protections on Wednesday aimed primarily at travelers’ growing frustration over airline fees.

articles.headline: Prices Surge as Investors Rush to Safety of Gold
articles.snippet: Platinum and palladium prices have risen, too, as investors seek safety from the European debt crisis, global inflation and political turmoil.
articles.abstract: Platinum and palladium prices have risen, too, as investors seek safety from the European debt crisis, global inflation and political turmoil.
articles.lead_paragraph: The price of gold rose above $1,500 an ounce on Wednesday for the first time, pushed higher by investor concerns about global inflation, government debt and turmoil in the Arab world.
